Air: the Reflexion is Stronger in the Superficies of Glass 
then of water, Still Stronger in the Superficies of Crystall 
& Strongest in the Superficies of Metalline Glasse. So in 
the confine of water & comon Glasse the reflexion is very 
weak, but yet Stronger then in the confine of water and 
Oyle or almost any other two liquors, & Still Stronger in 
the confine of water & C<s>h<\s>rystall or Metalline Glasse:
accordingly as those Mediums differ more or lesse in densi[ty]
So in the confine of comon Glasse & Crystall there is a 
weak reflexion, & a Stronger reflexion in the confine of 
com[m]on & Metalline Glasse: But in the confine of two 
Glasses of equal density, there is not any Sensible reflexion 
as was Showne in the 1st Observac[i]on. And the Same may 
be understood of the Sup[er]ficies of two Crystalls or liquors or 
any other Substances, in wch no refraction is caused, whence 
it comes to passe, that uniforme Mediums haue no Sensible 
reflexion, but in their externall Superficies, where they are 
adjacent to their Mediums of a different Density.
Prop: 2. The least parts of Naturall bodies are in 
Some measure transparent; And the opacity of those body[s]
riseth from the Multitude of Reflexions caused in their 
internall parts.
That this is So, will easily be granted by them, that 
haue bin conversant with Microscopes. And it may be 
also tryed by applying any Substance to a hole through wch 
Some Light is immitted into a dark roome. For how 
Opake Soever that Substance may Seeme in the open Air 
it will by that means appeare very manifestly transpar[ent]
if it be of a sufficient thinnesse. Onely Metalline body[s]
must be exempted, wch by reason of their excessive density 
Seeme to reflect almost all the Light incident on their 
first Superficies.
Prop. 3. Between the parts of opake or coloured 
Bodyes are many interstices replenished with Mediums 
of other Densities, as water between the tinging Corpuscles 
wherewith any Liquor is impregnated. Air between the 
aqueous Globules that constitute Clouds or Mists; and for 
the most part Spaces voyd of both Air and water, but yet 
p[er]haps replenished with Some Subtil<s>l<\s>er Medium between 
the parts of hard bodies.
